sen.j: 宮市（みやいち）は、古代日本において中国の制度を模倣して設けられた宮廷内の市場をいう。
sen.e: Miya-ichi was a market provided in the Imperial court in the ancient Japan that imitated the Chinese system.

sen.j: 中国では前漢代から唐代にかけて王・諸侯の宮廷に宮市という市場が設けられた。
sen.e: In China, from in the age of the former Han dynasty to in the age of Tang Dynasty, the courts of the kings and lords had the markets, so-called Palace markets.
In China, from the age of the former Han dynasty to the age of Tang Dynasty, the courts of the kings and lords had the markets called Palace markets.
sen.cmt: 前置詞の誤りおよび一部の表現を修正しました。
sen.e: In China, from the age of the former Han dynasty to the age of Tang Dynasty, the courts of the kings and lords had the markets called Palace markets.

sen.j: これらは当初は、単にその宮廷内に臨時の市場を設けたという娯楽的色彩の濃いものだった。
sen.e: At first, these were just temporary markets provided in the courts, and were very much like entertaining-type.

sen.j: しかし、唐の徳宗 (唐)の時代になると、宦官が庶民から宮廷に必要な物品を強制的に買い上げるものとなり、多くの弊害が生じた。
sen.e: However, in the times of Emperor Dezong (Tang Dynasty), adverse effects were produced when eunuchs forced to buy items, which were in demand for the court, from common people.

sen.j: 日本でもこれを模し、平安時代前期の承和 (日本)6年（839年）に宮市を設けたことがある（『続日本後紀』承和6年10月25日条）。
sen.e: In Japan, imitating these markets, the Miya-ichi were provided in 839, in the early Heian Period. ("Shoku Nihon Koki" (Later Chronicle of Japan Continued, from the article on October 25, 839)).

sen.e: In Japan, imitating these markets, the Miya-ichi were provided in 839, in the early Heian Period ("Shoku Nihon Koki" [Later Chronicle of Japan Continued, from the article on October 25, 839]).

sen.j: この場合、建礼門前に三個の帳舎を建て、舶来の唐物を陳列し、内蔵寮の官人と後宮女官等をして交易させたものを宮市と称している。
sen.e: In this case, three buildings built in front of the Kenrei-mon gate were referred to as Miya-ichi, displaying imported Chines goods so that govement officials from the Kuraryo (Bureau of Palace Storehouses) and court ladies from Kokyu palace (which was an imperial harem including the empress's residence) could exchange.

In this case, exchanges (referred to as Miya-ichi) were conducted with government officials from the Kuraryo (Bureau of Palace Storehouses) and court ladies from Kokyu palace (which was an imperial harem that included the empress's residence) in three buildings built in front of the Kenrei-mon gate that displayed imported Chinese goods.

sen.j: ちなみに、奈良時代においても、天平神護元年（765年）に称徳天皇が紀伊国行幸の途路に浜辺で市を開かせたことや、神護景雲3年（769年）に同じく称徳天皇が由義宮行幸の際に、河内国の市人に市を開かせたことが知られる（『続日本紀』天平神護元年10月19日条・神護景雲3年10月21日条）。
sen.e: Also in 765 in the Nara Period, a market on the beach provided by Emperor Shotoku, along with the route of the Imperial visit for Kii Province, and another market that the same Emperor Shotoku ordered merchants from Kwachi Province to open, at the time of the Imperial visit for Yugenomiya detached palace in 769, were known. (the articles of October 19, 765 and October 21, 769, according to the "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued)).

sen.j: 以上から、日本では権力者の強制売買による弊害は少なく、むしろ天皇の娯楽的な臨時公開市場的な性格が強いと思われる。
sen.e: This shows that in Japan, it is considered that adverse effects due to forced sales by the power were less, and the market was more entertaining for the Emperor as a temporary open market.
